lessons.title: Why financial literacy matters in Canada
body: Financial literacy affects daily decisions—from choosing no-fee banking to picking the right registered account. A few percent in fees or interest can compound to thousands over time.
Key Canadian choices include TFSA vs RRSP, fixed vs variable mortgages, and avoiding high‑interest credit products. Building simple habits (automation, comparing fees, reading statements) pays off.
Treat learning like reps at the gym: 5 minutes a day, small wins, steady compounding.

quiz.q: Higher fees and interest can compound into large costs over time.
Financial literacy only matters for high earners.

lessons.title: Define goals you can measure
body: Short‑term goals (≤3 years) like a $1,000 buffer need liquidity; long‑term goals (5+ years) like retirement can use market risk for growth.
Write goals with a number and a date (e.g., “$150/month to reach $1,800 in 12 months”).
Match the account to the goal: TFSA is flexible; RRSP is designed for retirement.

quiz.q: A vacation next year is a long‑term goal.
RRSPs are primarily for retirement savings.

lessons.title: Pay yourself first (automate it)
body: Set an automatic transfer on payday to a TFSA or high‑interest savings. Remove willpower from the equation.
Start small ($25–$50 per pay). Increase with raises or when debts are cleared.
Treat it as a bill to your future self.

quiz.q: Paying yourself first means saving before spending.
Automation mainly helps by boosting consistency.

lessons.title: Needs vs wants that you’ll actually follow
body: Start with 50/30/20 (needs/wants/saving+debt) as a baseline, then customize to your rent, childcare, or variable income.
Separate accounts or ‘buckets’ keep limits visible. Audit subscriptions quarterly.
Focus on sustainability, not perfection.

quiz.q: Groceries belong under needs.
A streaming upgrade is a need.

lessons.title: Habits > one‑off windfalls
body: Long‑run wealth usually comes from routine—consistent saving, avoiding high‑interest debt, and staying invested.
Starting early lets compounding work longer—even small amounts add up.
Track progress monthly; reset quickly after setbacks.

quiz.q: Small consistent savings often beat occasional windfalls.
Compounding benefits are larger when you start earlier.

lessons.title: What a budget actually does
body: A budget is a plan for where your dollars will go *before* the month begins. It aligns spending with goals and reduces surprises.
List after‑tax income, set category targets, then track briefly each week to stay aligned.
Use tools you’ll stick with: FCAC’s planner, a spreadsheet, or an app.

quiz.q: A budget’s main job is to plan and prioritize spending.
Budgets never change once set.

lessons.title: 50/30/20 as a starting point
body: Aim 50% needs, 30% wants, 20% saving+debt. If 20% is tough, begin at 5–10% and step up over time.
Use sinking funds for predictable annual costs (car maintenance, gifts).
Revisit monthly; adjust when life changes.

quiz.q: In 50/30/20, saving+debt is 20%.
You should never change the ratios.

lessons.title: Tracking without burnout
body: Weekly category checks beat daily receipt logging for most people.
Use alerts for big variances (e.g., dining‑out > budget).
If you share finances, agree on categories and a check‑in cadence.

quiz.q: Weekly check‑ins can keep you aligned without burnout.
Alerts for overspending help course‑correct sooner.

lessons.title: Adjusting when life changes
body: New job, rent increase, debt paid off—update the plan. Redirect freed‑up money to goals before lifestyle creep.
Create mini funds for seasonal costs (holidays, tuition).
Do an annual deep refresh to reflect bigger shifts.

quiz.q: Lifestyle creep can absorb freed‑up cash if you don’t redirect it.
Budgets should reflect life changes.

lessons.title: TFSA: tax‑free growth & withdrawals
body: A TFSA shelters growth *and* withdrawals from tax. It can hold cash, GICs, ETFs, and more—the name is a misnomer.
Room accumulates if you’re 18+ with a SIN and resident of Canada. Withdrawals add back room next calendar year.
Track your contribution room in CRA My Account. Over‑contributions face a penalty.

quiz.q: TFSA withdrawals are taxable income.
TFSA withdrawals create room again the next year.

lessons.title: RRSP: deduct now, pay later
body: RRSP contributions reduce taxable income; investments grow tax‑deferred.
Withdrawals are taxable—ideally in lower‑income retirement years or under HBP/LLP rules.
Unused room carries forward. Check your Notice of Assessment.

quiz.q: RRSP contributions reduce your taxable income.
RRSP withdrawals are always tax‑free.

lessons.title: FHSA: first home turbo
body: FHSA blends TFSA‑like tax‑free withdrawals for a first home with RRSP‑like deductibility of contributions (limits apply).
You can use FHSA with the RRSP Home Buyers’ Plan if you qualify.
Room mechanics and qualifying rules are specific—review before contributing.

quiz.q: FHSA withdrawals for a qualifying first home are tax‑free.
You can combine FHSA with HBP for the same purchase if eligible.

lessons.title: Risk and return 101
body: Higher expected return usually comes with higher volatility. Cash is stable but grows slowly; stocks can grow faster with bumps.
Align risk to time horizon—longer horizons can handle more equity exposure.
Focus on ranges and discipline, not predictions.

quiz.q: Stocks typically carry more volatility than GICs.
You can get high returns with no risk routinely.

lessons.title: Diversification & indexing
body: Diversification spreads risk across many holdings; index funds and broad ETFs do this cheaply.
Avoid concentration in single stocks or sectors unless you accept higher risk.
All‑in‑one asset‑allocation ETFs provide a simple diversified core.

quiz.q: A broad index ETF can hold hundreds of companies.
Diversification reduces the impact of one company failing.

lessons.title: Fees & MERs compound too
body: MERs reduce your net return every year. A 2% fee vs 0.25% can mean tens of thousands over decades.
Compare costs before buying; watch trading commissions and account fees.
Read fund fact sheets to see MER and risk rating.

quiz.q: Higher MERs leave you with more return.
Costs compound over time just like returns.

lessons.title: Asset mix & rebalancing
body: Decide your stock/bond/cash mix based on goals and risk tolerance.
Rebalance periodically (e.g., annually) to reset to targets—this buys low/sells high mechanically.
All‑in‑one ETFs can automate the process.

quiz.q: Rebalancing keeps you aligned to your target mix.
All‑in‑one ETFs can handle rebalancing for you.

lessons.title: Capital gains & dividends (non‑registered)
body: Outside registered accounts, realized capital gains are partially taxable; only when you sell. Eligible Canadian dividends may receive a dividend tax credit, lowering effective tax.
Inside registered accounts (TFSA/RRSP/FHSA), tax treatment differs—TFSA gains/withdrawals are tax‑free; RRSP withdrawals are taxable later.
Keep records for ACB (adjusted cost base) in taxable accounts.

quiz.q: Capital gains tax applies when gains are unrealized.
Eligible Canadian dividends may receive a tax credit.

lessons.title: Asset location for after‑tax returns
body: Place interest‑heavy assets in RRSP/TFSA when possible; keep tax‑efficient equity ETFs in taxable if needed.
Consider foreign withholding tax on dividends; RRSP treaties can differ from TFSA treatment.
Balance theory with simplicity—don’t over‑engineer small portfolios.

quiz.q: Asset location aims to improve after‑tax returns.
Foreign withholding taxes never matter in registered accounts.

lessons.title: DCA vs lump‑sum
body: Dollar‑cost averaging smooths entry by investing a fixed amount on a schedule; lump‑sum invests all at once.
Historically, lump‑sum often wins if markets have a positive drift, but DCA reduces regret and timing risk.
Pick the approach you’ll stick with, then automate.

quiz.q: DCA invests a fixed amount on a schedule.
Lump‑sum always beats DCA for every investor.

learnMore.label: OSC – Working with an advisor or firm

lessons.title: Behavioral guardrails
body: Create rules ahead of time: rebalancing bands, contribution dates, and a ‘cool‑off’ rule before selling.
Hide performance during market drawdowns if it causes panic selling.
Document your investment policy in one page and revisit annually.

quiz.q: Pre‑committing rules can reduce emotional decisions.
Checking portfolio value constantly reduces risk.
